Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: The pantry is stocked with kosher ingredients, and alternative snacks are readily available.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my computer, realizing the team meeting was about to start. As a colleague, I was expected to join, contribute, and show my engagement, even though the meeting would be recorded for anyone who missed it. I knew my manager valued visible participation, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged. But as I reached for a snack before the meeting, I noticed the only available option on the table was a box of pastries someone had brought in to celebrate a project milestone. They weren’t labeled, and I couldn’t be sure if they were kosher. My colleagues were already gathering, chatting and helping themselves, expecting everyone to join in the small celebration. I felt the pressure to be part of the group, to share in the moment, but I also felt the weight of my commitment to keeping kosher, especially when alternatives were usually available but not this time. My stomach tightened as I stood at the threshold, torn between my desire to belong and my need to honor my faith, unsure which expectation I could afford to disappoint.
